descript.abstract: This layer contains data for the sewer interceptor system in the Twin Cities metropolitan area. Owned, operated and maintained by the Metropolitan Council Environmental Services division, the interceptor system provides the link from community sewer systems to the wastewater treatment facilities in the seven county metropolitan area.
descript.purpose: To provide a digital inventory of Metropolitan Council, Environmental Services division owned pipelines for maintenance, planning and analysis.
descript.supplinf: Twin Cities 7 County Metropolitan Area. This includes the counties of Anoka, Carver, Dakota, Hennepin, Ramsey, Scott and Washington in Minnesota.

timeperd.current: Dataset is up-to-date as of the Time Period of Content date.

theme.themekey: sewer, sewers, waste water, sewage, sewerage, sewer interceptors, sewer systems, utilites

place.placekey: Twin Cities, Anoka County, Carver County, Dakota County, Hennepin County, Ramsey County, Scott County, Washington County

citeinfo.title: Sewer Interceptor System, Abandoned Sewer Interceptors, Lift Stations, Sewer Interceptor Meter Stations

dataqual.complete: Entire seven county geographic area is covered.

horizpa.horizpar: The positional accuracy of the dataset has not been tested under the National Standards for Spatial Data Accuracy. The positional accuracy of the dataset is estimated to be 20 ft.

procstep.procdesc:
This dataset was derived from as-built plan drawings. The data were transferred to ETAK street base files and later converted to match a 1992 (?) Minnesota Department of Transportation street base.
The Metropolitan Council is in the process of developing parallel data using GPS locations for more accurate positioning.

overview.eaover:
LINE ATTRIBUTES
ID_NO: Name of interceptor
SYMBOL: Symbol for the type of interceptor pipe * 1 = Gravity: Flow is moved by gravity, based on the slope of the pipe. * 2 = Forcemain: Pressurized sewer pipe - requires pumps to push flow until it can move by gravity again. * 3 = Siphon: A pipe designed to go under obstacles such as rivers. The entry point is higher than the exit, creating pressure that pushes the material through the pipe. * 4 = Outfall/Effluent: Pipe which transports treated effluent from the treatment plant to the outfall or discharge point. * 5 = Low-head Crossing: A pipe designed to go under smaller obstacles, such as creeks. * 6 = Misc. pipe: Wide variety of sewer and non-sewer features. Can include city sewer pipe which connects remote MCES features, Access tunnels, MCES Air pipes, and more. (data not included in "Limited Attributes" dataset) * 8 = Crossover: General category for pipes intentionally designed to divert flow; often controlled by valve features but not always. Can include pipes which bypass meter sites, crossover pipes which connect two barrels of a forcemain, and more.
Int_Sect: Unique identifier for individual sections of the interceptor.
DIMEN: Diameter/Dimension of pipe if circular
Status: Status of interceptor pipe * Abandoned = existing pipe has been abandoned * Offline = existing pipe is not active * Online = existing pipe is active and under use
created_user: Editor tracking attribute. Indicates which GIS user created the record.
created_date: Editor tracking attribute. Indicates when the record was created.
last_edited_user: Editor tracking attribute. Indicates which GIS user last edited the record.
last_edited_date: Editor tracking attribute. Indicates when the record was last edited.

distinfo.distliab: NOTICE: The Geographic Information System (GIS) Data to which this notice is attached are made available pursuant to the Minnesota Government Data Practices Act (Minnesota Statutes Chapter 13). THE GIS DATA ARE PROVIDED TO YOU AS IS AND WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY AS TO THEIR PERFORMANCE, MERCHANTABILITY, OR FITNESS FOR ANY PARTICULAR PURPOSE. The GIS Data were developed by the Metropolitan Council for its own internal business purposes. The Metropolitan Council does not represent or warrant that the GIS Data or the data documentation are error-free, complete, current, or accurate. You are responsible for any consequences resulting from your use of the GIS Data or your reliance on the GIS Data. You should consult the data documentation for this particular GIS Data to determine the limitations of the GIS Data and the precision with which the GIS Data may depict distance, direction, location, or other geographic features. If you transmit or provide the GIS Data (or any portion of it) to another user, it is recommended that the GIS Data include a copy of this disclaimer and this metadata.
